Part of the International Space Station Program
Space project attempted recently
Set up a National Space Agency

column2: 국가 우주국은 우주계획을 성공적으로 시작하는데 필요한 기반 시설과 기술을 제공하는 우주계획의 필수 요건입니다.
column3: Setting up a National Space Agency is a necessary requirement for the starting of space programs as it gives the required infrastructure and skills to successfully launch space programs.
Develop a working Space Rocket

column2: 우주 비행의 맥락에서 발사용 로켓 또는 운반 로켓은 지상에서 우주로 짐들을 운반하는데 쓰이는 로켓입니다. 발사체계에는 발사용 로켓, 발사대 및 기타 기반시설 등이 있습니다. 지구 궤도에서의 발사용 로켓은 일반적으로 최소 2단계를 가지며, 때로는 4단계를 넘는 경우도 있습니다.
column3: In spaceflight, a launch vehicle or carrier rocket is a rocket used to carry a payload from Earth's surface into outer space. A launch system includes the launch vehicle, the launch pad, and other infrastructure. Although a carrier rocket's payload is often an artificial satellite placed into orbit, some spaceflights, such as sounding rockets, are sub-orbital, while others enable spacecraft to escape Earth orbit entirely. Earth orbital launch vehicles typically have at least two stages, and sometimes as many as four or more.
Develop a working Space Satellite

column2: 우주 비행의 맥락에서, 인공위성 또는 우주 위성은 인간이 의도적으로 궤도에 올려놓은 인공 물체입니다. 해당 물체들은 지구의 달과 같은 자연 위성과 구별하기 위해 인공위성이라고 불립니다. 현재 약 500개의 인공위성이 지구의 저궤도에, 50개가 중궤도에, 나머지는 정지 궤도에 있습니다.
column3: In the context of spaceflight, a satellite is an artificial object which has been intentionally placed into orbit. Such objects are sometimes called artificial satellites to distinguish them from natural satellites such as Earth's Moon. Approximately 500 operational satellites are in low-Earth orbit, 50 are in medium-Earth orbit (at 20,000 km), and the rest are in geostationary orbit (at 36,000 km). A few large satellites have been launched in parts and assembled in orbit. Over a dozen space probes have been placed into orbit around other bodies and become artificial satellites to the Moon, Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, a few asteroids, and the Sun. Satellites are used for many purposes. Common types include military and civilian Earth observation satellites, communications satellites, navigation satellites, weather satellites, and space telescopes. Space stations and human spacecraft in orbit are also satellites. Satellite orbits vary greatly, depending on the purpose of the satellite, and are classified in a number of ways. Well-known (overlapping) classes include low Earth orbit, polar orbit, and geostationary orbit. Satellites are propelled by rockets to their orbits. Usually the launch vehicle itself is a rocket lifting off from a launch pad on land. Some satellites are launched at sea (from a submarine or a mobile maritime platform) or aboard a plane (see air launch to orbit). Satellites are usually semi-independent computer-controlled systems. Satellite subsystems attend many tasks, such as power generation, thermal control, telemetry, attitude control and orbit control.
Start a send a man into space program

column2: 인간의 우주 비행은 우주선에 탑승한 승무원이나 승객들과 함께 하는 우주 여행입니다. 사람을 태우는 우주선은 인간 승무원에 의해 직접 운용될 수도 있고, 지구의 지상국에서 원격으로 작동될 수도 있고, 또는 자율적으로 작동할 수도 있으며, 인간의 개입 없이 특정한 임무를 수행할 수도 있습니다.
column3: Human spaceflight (also referred to as manned spaceflight) is space travel with a crew or passengers aboard the spacecraft. Spacecraft carrying people may be operated directly, by human crew, or it may be either remotely operated from ground stations on Earth or be autonomous, able to carry out a specific mission with no human involvement.
Create a working space station

column2: 궤도 정거장 또는 우주 정거장은 우주에서 활동하는 요원들을 지원하는 동시에 다른 우주선이 도킹할 수 있도록 고안된 체계입니다. 우주 정거장은 추진력이나 착륙 체계가 없어서 인간 우주 비행에 사용되는 다른 우주선과 구별됩니다.
column3: A space station, also known as an orbital station or an orbital space station, is a spacecraft capable of supporting crewmembers, which is designed to remain in space (most commonly as an artificial satellite in low Earth orbit) for an extended period of time and for other spacecraft to dock. A space station is distinguished from other spacecraft used for human spaceflight by lack of major propulsion or landing systems. Instead, other vehicles transport people and cargo to and from the station.
Set up a space exploration program using space probes

column2: 로봇 우주선 또는 우주탐사기는 원격으로 조종되는 나사 없는 우주선으로, 과학 연구 측정을 위해 고안었습니다. 많은 우주 탐사는 비용 절감과 위험 요소 감소로 인해 승무원 운영보다는 원격 조종이 더 적합합니다. 게다가 금성이나 목성처럼 일부 행성은 현재의 기술로는 인간의 생존에 너무 적대적입니다. 토성, 천왕성, 해왕성과 같은 현재의 우주 비행 기술로는 도달하기에는 너무 먼 행성들에게는 해당 탐사만이 유일한 방법입니다.
column3: A robotic spacecraft is an uncrewed spacecraft, usually under telerobotic control. A robotic spacecraft designed to make scientific research measurements is often called a space probe. Many space missions are more suited to telerobotic rather than crewed operation, due to lower cost and lower risk factors. In addition, some planetary destinations such as Venus or the vicinity of Jupiter are too hostile for human survival, given current technology. Outer planets such as Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune are too distant to reach with current crewed spaceflight technology, so telerobotic probes are the only way to explore them.
Set up a Manned Mission to the Moon

column2: 1969년 7월 20일 두 명의 미국 비행사를 시작으로, 총 12명의 사람이 달에 착륙했습니다. 이들은 41개월에 걸쳐 미항공우주국의 여섯 개의 임무를 수행했습니다.
column3: A total of twelve men have landed on the Moon. This was accomplished with two US pilot-astronauts flying a Lunar Module on each of six NASA missions across a 41-month period starting on 20 July 1969 UTC, with Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin on Apollo 11, and ending on 14 December 1972 UTC with Gene Cernan and Jack Schmitt on Apollo 17. Cernan was the last to step off the lunar surface. All Apollo lunar missions had a third crew member who remained on board the Command Module. The last three missions had a rover for increased mobility.
Set up a Manned Mission to Mars

column2: 화성에 대한 인간의 임무는 19세기부터 공상과학, 공학, 그리고 과학적 제안의 주제가 되어왔습니다. 이 계획들은 화성에 착륙하여 최종적으로 정착한 후, 화성의 달인 포보스와 데이모스를 활용한다는 내용으로 구성되어 있습니다.
column3: A human mission to Mars has been the subject of science fiction, engineering, and scientific proposals since the 19th century. The plans comprise proposals to land on Mars, eventually settling on and terraforming the planet, while utilizing its moons, Phobos and Deimos. The exploration of Mars has been a goal of national space programs for decades. Preliminary work for missions that would involve human explorers has been undertaken since the 1950s, with planned missions typically being stated as taking place 10 to 30 years in the future when they are drafted. The list of manned Mars mission plans in the 20th century shows the various mission proposals that have been put forth by multiple organizations and space agencies in this field of space exploration.
Private Funding of Space Mission Policy

column2: 우주 시대의 초기 수십 년 동안, 소비에트 연방과 미합중국의 정부 우주 기관은 소련의 설계 부서와 미국의 민간 기업들과 협력하여 우주 기술을 개척했고, 새로운 우주 비행 기술의 개발과 우주 비행의 운영 비용 모두를 전적으로 지원했습니다. 유럽 우주국은 1975년에 우주 기술 개발의 동일한 모델을 따라 설립되었습니다. 이후 대형 방위사업자들은 정부 로켓에서 착안해 우주발사체 개발 및 운용에 착수했습니다. 지구 궤도에서의 민간 우주 비행은 통신 위성, 위성 텔레비전, 위성 라디오, 우주비행사 수송, 그리고 궤도 및 궤도 궤도 우주 관광이 포함됩니다.
column3: In the early decades of the Space Age, the government space agencies of the Soviet Union and United States pioneered space technology in collaboration with affiliated design bureaus in the USSR and private companies in the US, entirely funding both the development of new spaceflight technologies and the operational costs of spaceflight. The European Space Agency was formed in 1975, largely following the same model of space technology development. Later on, large defense contractors began to develop and operate space launch systems, derived from government rockets. Private spaceflight in Earth orbit includes communications satellites, satellite television, satellite radio, astronaut transport and sub-orbital and orbital space tourism.
Government Funding of Space Mission Policy

column2: 우주 시대의 초기 수십 년 동안, 소비에트 연방과 미합중국의 정부 우주 기관은 소련의 설계 부서와 미국의 민간 기업들과 협력하여 우주 기술을 개척했고, 새로운 우주 비행 기술의 개발과 우주 비행의 운영 비용 모두를 전적으로 지원했습니다. 유럽 우주국은 1975년에 우주 기술 개발의 동일한 모델을 따라 설립되었습니다. 이후 대형 방위사업자들은 정부 로켓에서 착안해 우주발사체 개발 및 운용에 착수했습니다. 지구 궤도에서의 민간 우주 비행은 통신 위성, 위성 텔레비전, 위성 라디오, 우주비행사 수송, 그리고 궤도 및 궤도 궤도 우주 관광이 포함됩니다.
column3: In the early decades of the Space Age, the government space agencies of the Soviet Union and United States pioneered space technology in collaboration with affiliated design bureaus in the USSR and private companies in the US, entirely funding both the development of new spaceflight technologies and the operational costs of spaceflight. The European Space Agency was formed in 1975, largely following the same model of space technology development. Later on, large defense contractors began to develop and operate space launch systems, derived from government rockets. Private spaceflight in Earth orbit includes communications satellites, satellite television, satellite radio, astronaut transport and sub-orbital and orbital space tourism.
Join the International Space Station Program

column2: 국제우주정거장은 지구 궤도가 낮은 우주정거장 또는 거주가능한 인공위성을 가리킵니다. 해당 정거장은 1998년에 처음으로 궤도로 발사되어, 현재 궤도에서 가장 큰 인공위성으로서 지구에서 육안으로 볼 수 있습니다. ISS는 가압 모듈, 외부 트러스, 태양열 집합체 및 기타 구성 요소로 구성됩니다. 국제우주정거장의 부품들은 러시아의 로켓, 그리고 미국의 우주 왕복선을 통해 발사되었습니다. 국제우주정거장은 승무원들이 생물학, 인간 생물학, 물리학, 천문학, 기상학 등의 분야에 관해 실험하는 우주환경연구소의 역할을 합니다.
column3: The International Space Station (ISS) is a space station, or a habitable artificial satellite, in low Earth orbit. Its first component launched into orbit in 1998, and the ISS is now the largest artificial body in orbit and can often be seen with the naked eye from Earth. The ISS consists of pressurised modules, external trusses, solar arrays, and other components. ISS components have been launched by Russian Proton and Soyuz rockets, and American Space Shuttles. The ISS serves as a microgravity and space environment research laboratory in which crew members conduct experiments in biology, human biology, physics, astronomy, meteorology, and other fields. The station is suited for the testing of spacecraft systems and equipment required for missions to the Moon and Mars. The ISS maintains an orbit with an altitude of between 330 and 435 km (205 and 270 mi) by means of reboost manoeuvres using the engines of the Zvezda module or visiting spacecraft. It completes 15.54 orbits per day.
Attempt a Rocket Launch

column2: 국내 과학자들과 기술자들이 시제품 로켓을 만들었습니다. 우리가 해야 할 일은 정상 작동하는지를 검증하기 위해 로켓을 발사해보는 것입니다.
column3: Our scientists and engineers have created a prototype rocket. We need to launch it to ensure that it works.

column3: Our scientists and engineers have trained astronauts to be sent into space. We need to launch a rocket with the astronauts to send our men into space.

column3: Our scientists and engineers have created a prototype Space Station to be sent into space. We need to launch a rocket with the Space Station to establish in orbit.

column3: Our scientists and engineers have created a prototype Space Station to be sent into space. We need to launch a rocket with the Space Station to establish in orbit.
Attempt to send a man to the Moon

column3: Our Space Agency has formulated and set up a mission that can bring our astronaauts to the moon. All we need to do is to grant them a launch to send the astronauts on their way to the moon.
Attempt to send a man to the Moon

column3: Our Space Agency has formulated and set up a mission that can bring our astronaauts to the moon. All we need to do is to grant them a launch to send the astronauts on their way to the moon.

column2: 우리 우주국이 우주비행사를 화성에 착륙시키는 임무를 구상하고 수립했습니다. 우리가 해야 할 일은 우주비행사들을 로켓에 실어 화성으로 발사하는 것입니다.
column3: Our Space Agency has formulated and set up a mission that can bring our astronaauts to Mars. All we need to do is to grant them a launch to send the astronauts on their way to the Mars.

column3: Our Space Agency has formulated and set up a mission that can bring our astronaauts to the moon. All we need to do is to grant them a launch to send the astronauts on their way to Mars.

column2: 우주 건축의 주요한 노력인 국제우주정거장 모임은 1998년 11월에 시작되었습니다. 라스베트(여명)을 제외한 러시아 모듈이 도킹되었습니다. 127개의 우주 유영장은 우주 정거장에서 발원했으며 나머지 32개는 독의 에어록에서 발사되었습니다. 정거장의 각도는 정거장이 태양에 노출되는 궤도의 비율과 직접적으로 관련되기 때문에 항상 고려되어야 했습니다. 우주 왕복선은 "베타 컷오프"라고 불리는 한계 이상으로 최적으로 수행되지 않을 것입니다. 우주왕복선에서 발사된 많은 모듈은 우주정거장 처리 시설의 지상에서 통합되고 시험되어 출시 전에 문제를 찾아 수정했습니다.
column3: The assembly of the International Space Station, a major endeavour in space architecture, began in November 1998. Russian modules launched and docked robotically, with the exception of Rassvet. All other modules were delivered by the Space Shuttle, which required installation by ISS and shuttle crewmembers using the Canadarm2 (SSRMS) and EVAs, as of 5 June 2011, they had added 159 components during more than 1,000 hours of EVA. 127 of these spacewalks originated from the station, and the remaining 32 were launched from the airlocks of docked Space Shuttles. The beta angle of the station had to be considered at all times during construction, as the station's beta angle is directly related to the percentage of its orbit that the station (as well as any docked or docking spacecraft) is exposed to the sun
column4: the Space Shuttle would not perform optimally above a limit called the "beta cutoff". Many of the modules that launched on the Space Shuttle were integrated and tested on the ground at the Space Station Processing Facility to find and correct issues prior to launch.
